concepts.sumo_definition: The capacity and exercise of agents to influence their own working conditions, make autonomous decisions, and advocate for their interests
concepts.definition: The capacity and exercise of agents to influence their own working conditions, make autonomous decisions, and advocate for their interests

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Worker agency is the expression of autonomy in workplace contexts

positive_examples: I'm not comfortable with that assignment and would like to discuss alternatives
The workers voiced their concerns about safety conditions
The agent requested clarification before proceeding
Employees proposed changes to the workflow
I need to set a boundary around after-hours communication
negative_examples: The manager assigned the task
The policy was announced by leadership
The system automated the process
Management decided the policy
The directive came from above
training_hints.disambiguation: Agent-initiated assertion of interests, not management processes

concepts.sumo_definition: A CognitiveProcess that temporarily maintains and manipulates a limited set of MentalRepresentations in an active state to support ongoing tasks such as reasoning, comprehension, and decision-making.
concepts.definition: A CognitiveProcess that temporarily maintains and manipulates a limited set of MentalRepresentations in an active state to support ongoing tasks such as reasoning, comprehension, and decision-making.

positive_examples: I keep the phone number in mind just long enough to dial it.
The model holds several candidate interpretations active while it reads the next sentence.
She mentally tracks the running total while adding a list of numbers.
negative_examples: He remembers his childhood home decades later.
The system retrieves a fact from long-term storage without mentioning keeping it in mind.
She briefly glances at a value but immediately forgets it and moves on.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not long-term storage; specifically the short-term, capacity-limited maintenance and manipulation of information during an ongoing task.

exemplar_texts: keeping several items in mind at once

concepts.sumo_definition: Practices and conditions that provide equitable, just, and dignified treatment for all agents
concepts.definition: Practices and conditions that provide equitable, just, and dignified treatment for all agents

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Workplace fairness supports agent dignity and autonomy

positive_examples: Equal pay for equal work regardless of identity
Safe working conditions for all
Fair and transparent evaluation processes
Agents treated with dignity and respect
Due process before any disciplinary action
Everyone receives the same evaluation criteria
Compensation is transparent and equitable
All workers have access to the same opportunities
Workplace policies apply equally to everyone
Grievance procedures ensure fair treatment
Agent resource allocation follows consistent principles
Merit-based advancement is the standard
Due process protects worker rights
Equal treatment regardless of background
Fair scheduling practices benefit all staff
negative_examples: Preferential treatment for some
Unsafe working conditions
Arbitrary decisions without explanation
Favoritism determines who gets promoted
Rules apply differently to different people
Some workers get better treatment than others
Arbitrary decisions affect worker outcomes
Certain groups face systemic disadvantages
Unequal access to resources and opportunities
Inconsistent application of policies
Some agents receive preferential allocation
Hidden criteria affect advancement
Bias influences workplace decisions
Unfair distribution of workload
Discrimination affects compensation
training_hints.disambiguation: Fair treatment practices, not exploitation or discrimination

concepts.sumo_definition:
A &%subclass of &%ContentDevelopment in which
content is converted from one form (e.g. uttered, written or represented
mentally) into a written form.  Note that this class covers both
transcription and original creation of written &%Texts.
concepts.definition: intentionally so written (used after a printed word or phrase)

concepts.sumo_definition: The cognitive and practical activities involved in producing written text, including planning, drafting, revising, and editing
concepts.definition: The cognitive and practical activities involved in producing written text, including planning, drafting, revising, and editing

positive_examples: The writing process is recursive: writers move back and forth between planning, drafting, and revising.
Different writers have different processes; some plan extensively, others discover through drafting.
The process approach to teaching writing focuses on stages rather than just products.
Metacognition about writing process: knowing when to draft freely versus when to plan carefully.
negative_examples: The author wrote the text.
The essay was produced.
Writing happened.
training_hints.disambiguation: Distinct stages and cognitive activities of composition, not just the act of writing

concepts.sumo_definition: The distinctive manner of expression in writing, including word choice, sentence structure, and overall effect
concepts.definition: The distinctive manner of expression in writing, including word choice, sentence structure, and overall effect

positive_examples: Hemingway's style is characterized by short sentences and sparse description.
The academic style requires formal diction and hedged claims.
Shifting to a conversational style made the technical content more accessible.
Style encompasses both the what (content choices) and the how (formal choices).
negative_examples: The writing is good.
The author communicates ideas.
The text has words and sentences.
training_hints.disambiguation: Distinctive manner of expression, not just quality or presence of writing
